> So, I can think of two possiblities:
> 
> Leave it as is
> extract another class that just does the validation

I think there are some common logic like applying `stateRestoreCallback.restore(key, value)` for both restore and active tasks (i.e. `restorer.restore` just calls `callback.restore`). But I agree that the `changelogReader.restore()` function is actually wrapping a lot of functional logic including fetching. So the refactoring itself would be much larger than I originally thought, that would include:

1. share the same common function for both processor state manager and standby tasks that are applying for the same restore consumer.
2. extract the logic of `obeying offset limit` in standby tasks out of the restoration logic to make it more commonly used among these two scenarios.

So let's keep this as is for now, and we can consider doing that in a later PR.
@enothereska Could you provide a rough estimate on the optimized portion for this PR?
@ijuma Please have a reivew on this PR. Thanks.
LGTM
I saw improvements of around 2%. Small, but every little bit matters, esp at high speed.

@jozi-k It might not be due to your PR, but rather from the head of the trunk. Could you try rebasing on trunk and see if you can first reproduce the failure locally?

@apurvam The goal of the test was to verify non-disruptive upgrade from non-secure to secure mode by adding a new protocol and making updates with incremental bounces. But somewhere along the line the test was modified and the test ended up not testing our recommended upgrade path. Instead it tests a path where the cluster is unavailable while is being upgraded. I don't think we need to test that path when there is a recommended alternative.

I think this change to the test is necessary to test the right upgrade scenario and avoid consumer timeouts. But I am not entirely sure it fixes the specific issue in the JIRA.

Thanks for the PR. I looked this in more detail and it looks like we eventually throw `KafkaException` for this case. In the consumer, we throw `InterruptException` (which is a non-checked version of `InterruptedException` that inherits from `KafkaException`). Seems like we should do the same here. That class sets the interrupt in the constructor.

Thank you very much for the PR @rajinisivaram. I am trying to understand where we do the disruptive change. We currently start the broker with the plaintext and client protocol ports open:

```python
        self.kafka.security_protocol = client_protocol
        self.kafka.interbroker_security_protocol = "PLAINTEXT"
        self.kafka.start()
```

We then start to produce and consume via `client_protocol` and do the following:

```python
       # Roll cluster to include inter broker security protocol.
        self.kafka.interbroker_security_protocol = broker_protocol
        self.kafka.open_port(client_protocol)
        self.kafka.open_port(broker_protocol)
        self.bounce()
```

We change the inter-broker protocol, open the ports for client (which seems unnecessary) and broker protocol and then bounce the brokers. The changes should only take effect when we bounce the brokers, right? So, I don't see any period where the we do a disruptive change, but I could be missing something.
Oh, I see. We need to open port with broker protocol for every broker before we change the inter broker protocol and bounce the broker. Got it, thanks.

@ewencp @ijuma - i've been through the java modules and added checkstyle. Adjusted the defaults a bit to be more lenient (so i don't scare too many people). Also added a bunch of suppressions (i didn't want to change any code in doing this).

The tests will fail when there are no source nodes defined in the test topology. Also, if the defined source nodes are not related with partitions, the tests will also fail due to the NullPointerException in `StreamTask` 125: 
               
   ```
final SourceNode source = findSource(partition);   // <- here.  if partitions and source nodes don't match source will be null
final TimestampExtractor sourceTimestampExtractor = source.getTimestampExtractor() != null ? source.getTimestampExtractor() : defaultTimestampExtractor;
```


Maybe we should add extra check specifically for that issue, when validating the topology.
Seems like you need to adjust the suppressions @dguy.
@ijuma - yep :-(
